title: Demographics of Toronto
summary: The demographics of Toronto, Ontario, Canada make Toronto one of the most multicultural and multiracial cities in the world. In 2016, 51.5 percent of the residents of the city proper belonged to a visible minority group, compared with 49.1% in 2011,[1][2] and 13.6% in 1981.[3] Toronto also has established ethnic neighbourhoods such as the multiple Chinatowns, Corso Italia, Little Italy, Little India, Greektown, Koreatown, Little Jamaica, Little Portugal and Roncesvalles, which celebrate the city's multiculturalism.[4] Data from the suburban municipalities are also included for some metrics as they are part of the Toronto CMA.
